issue.title: Add ability to create a proxied service using ProxyManager
Add HEALTHCHECK to Dockerfile
issue.body:
Hi!

Thanks for the useful software! After using localstack in a docker-compose project I thought it might be beneficial for a container health-check to be supported directly by the [localstack/localstack](https://hub.docker.com/r/localstack/localstack/#!) container. As it would be hard to provide tests for something like this I provided a screenshot of `docker ps` with these changes in my local environment.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/771345/174446367-e169e48e-853a-46c0-86b0-1a13e70a9b60.png)

> Note: To get this branch working in your own local environment you'll need to either build and run the Docker container directly or update the `docker-compose.yml` file to build from the local Dockerfile and not pull an image from Dockerhub.

I'm assuming there's some build process in the localstack CI/CD that will generate the appropriate container image and push it to Dockerhub. If there are additional changes necessary for this I'll be more than happy to implement them with some guidance.

Thanks for considering my PR!

_Commit message below_

---

Adds a healthcheck to Dockerfile and Dockerfile.rh. Using curl it will
ping the /health endpoint every 10s, starting 15s after the container
has started running. If the /health endpoint returns any failure
response the container will be marked unhealthy.

There are 2 primary motivations for adding this directly to the Dockerfile:

1. Potentially less boilerplate in docker-compose.yml files that make use of
   localstack.
2. Docker container health status is no longer reliant on docker-compose
   to determine. If you're running just the localstack container
   you'll still be able to get access to the health.

**Please refer to the contribution guidelines in the README when submitting PRs.**

comment.body:
Thanks for the useful feedback @alexrashed. I believe the changes I submitted are what you're looking for. My own tests also confirmed that the health check was working as expected when I run `docker ps` and `docker compose ps`.

FWIW, during the testing of this I also had the container go into an unhealthy state and I can confirm that nothing was restarted. If there are any other concerns or adjustments that need to made please let me know!

commits.message: Use healthcheck cmd account for port changes

issue.title: The functional API to emulate Attributes is missing Inject features.
Logic Constraints
issue.body:
### Discussed in https://github.com/cspray/annotated-container/discussions/44
Originally posted by **cspray** April 3, 2022 Annotated Container has the capacity to analyze your annotations and tell you when there might be something wrong, they're called _logical constraints_. Though this system is not well-documented at the moment, you can find relevant code in the `Cspray\AnnotatedContainer\LogicalConstraint` namespace. This document is intended to act as a long-running list for the types of logical constraints that have been accounted for, are planned to account for, or are intentionally not going to account for. A future phase of the project will involve implementing the logical constraints listed here. Constraints are categorized by their type. The current constraint types are: - **Notice** These might indicate something is wrong but could be handled at runtime - **Warning** There is a large probability that this constraint violation will result in some error - **Critical** It is all but certain that attempting to use the code in this configuration will result in an error. ## Accounted For Constraints - [x] If an abstract service does not have any concrete services defined for it. _Warning_ - [x] If an abstract service has more than 1 alias defined for it. _Notice_ ## Planned to Account For Constraints While this is intended to be an exhaustive list it might be possible that conditions exist the author has not considered. If you believe that there's a violation missing in this list of constraints please comment below. ### Critical - [ ] If you duplicate the name of a `#[Service]`. - [ ] If you annotate a class method with `#[ServiceDelegate]` that has private or protected visibility. ### Warning - [ ] If you annotate a class property with `#[Inject]` without also annotating the class with `#[Configuration]`. _Warning_ ### Notice ## Intentionally Will-Not-Fix _No known logical constraints will be ignored._

issue.title: Add HEALTHCHECK to Dockerfile
issue.body:
Hi!

Thanks for the useful software! After using localstack in a docker-compose project I thought it might be beneficial for a container health-check to be supported directly by the [localstack/localstack](https://hub.docker.com/r/localstack/localstack/#!) container. As it would be hard to provide tests for something like this I provided a screenshot of `docker ps` with these changes in my local environment.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/771345/174446367-e169e48e-853a-46c0-86b0-1a13e70a9b60.png)

> Note: To get this branch working in your own local environment you'll need to either build and run the Docker container directly or update the `docker-compose.yml` file to build from the local Dockerfile and not pull an image from Dockerhub.

I'm assuming there's some build process in the localstack CI/CD that will generate the appropriate container image and push it to Dockerhub. If there are additional changes necessary for this I'll be more than happy to implement them with some guidance.

Thanks for considering my PR!

_Commit message below_

---

Adds a healthcheck to Dockerfile and Dockerfile.rh. Using curl it will
ping the /health endpoint every 10s, starting 15s after the container
has started running. If the /health endpoint returns any failure
response the container will be marked unhealthy.

There are 2 primary motivations for adding this directly to the Dockerfile:

1. Potentially less boilerplate in docker-compose.yml files that make use of
   localstack.
2. Docker container health status is no longer reliant on docker-compose
   to determine. If you're running just the localstack container
   you'll still be able to get access to the health.

**Please refer to the contribution guidelines in the README when submitting PRs.**

comment.body: @dfangl Thanks! I wasn't aware of the `--no-healthcheck` option. I think that actually would cover the case brought up for 1-off containers without needing to make any changes.

issue.title: Add HEALTHCHECK to Dockerfile
issue.body:
Hi!

Thanks for the useful software! After using localstack in a docker-compose project I thought it might be beneficial for a container health-check to be supported directly by the [localstack/localstack](https://hub.docker.com/r/localstack/localstack/#!) container. As it would be hard to provide tests for something like this I provided a screenshot of `docker ps` with these changes in my local environment.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/771345/174446367-e169e48e-853a-46c0-86b0-1a13e70a9b60.png)

> Note: To get this branch working in your own local environment you'll need to either build and run the Docker container directly or update the `docker-compose.yml` file to build from the local Dockerfile and not pull an image from Dockerhub.

I'm assuming there's some build process in the localstack CI/CD that will generate the appropriate container image and push it to Dockerhub. If there are additional changes necessary for this I'll be more than happy to implement them with some guidance.

Thanks for considering my PR!

_Commit message below_

---

Adds a healthcheck to Dockerfile and Dockerfile.rh. Using curl it will
ping the /health endpoint every 10s, starting 15s after the container
has started running. If the /health endpoint returns any failure
response the container will be marked unhealthy.

There are 2 primary motivations for adding this directly to the Dockerfile:

1. Potentially less boilerplate in docker-compose.yml files that make use of
   localstack.
2. Docker container health status is no longer reliant on docker-compose
   to determine. If you're running just the localstack container
   you'll still be able to get access to the health.

**Please refer to the contribution guidelines in the README when submitting PRs.**

comment.body:
@thrau Thank you for bringing this up! I wouldn't necessarily want to impede on this type of workflow. I'd be open to providing a way to "fake" the health check for this type of use case. For example:

```
FAKE_HEALTHCHECK=1 docker run ...
```

If this is explicitly set it can be assumed there's some reason, for example a 1-off, and you know what you're doing.

Alternatively, multiple Dockerfile could be provided. Perhaps this Dockerfile becomes the one to use for one-off running and a `Dockerfile.infra` (or similar) has the healthcheck. I'm not familiar enough with the project to be able to know what other repercussions this might have.

From a technically pure perspective the separate Dockerfile feels like a better solution. Faking the healthcheck feels a bit hacky.

issue.title: CacheAwareContainerDefinitionCompiler is dependent on ordering of directories

milestone.title: v0.7 Release
milestone.description: A release focused on providing more thorough documentation, interactions with Annotated Container on the command line, and marking renamed items for deprecation.

issue.body: The `CacheAwareContainerDefinitionCompiler` generates a file name in the given cache directory by calling `join()` on the directories that were scanned and passing the resulting string to `md5()`. This implementation would not properly handle if the same directories present in different orders. Tests should be written to ensure that using the cache aware compiler works as expected regardless of the ordering of the scanned directories.

milestone.title: v0.8 Release
milestone.description: Expected to be final cleanup, removal of previously deprecated items, and final documentation review before 1.0 release.

issue.title: Re-evaluate some problematic names to determine alternatives and mark for deprecation

payload.description: The website source for Annotated Container
The website source for Annotated Container

issue.title: Support implicitly determining ServiceDelegate based on method return type

milestone.title: v1.0+ and Beyond
milestone.description: Features that are intended to be implemented after a 1.0 release, the API has stabilized, and a user-base has been established to warrant the effort required.

issue.body: Currently the `#[ServiceDelegate]` Attribute requires that you provide the FCQN of the Service that should be created by the annotated method. If the method includes the return type for an object we could use that instead and only require the Service be passed to `#[ServiceDelegate]` in situations where the return type cannot be used to infer it.

issue.title: Re-evaluate whether non-shared services are functionality we should support

milestone.title: v1.0+ and Beyond
milestone.description: Features that are intended to be implemented after a 1.0 release, the API has stabilized, and a user-base has been established to warrant the effort required.

payload.description: Dependency Injection framework to configure a PSR-11 Container with Attributes!

commits.message:
Remove ability to not share a service (#106)

Through more thorough testing of creating non-shared services and
services that depended on other non-shared services it was decied there
was too much confusion and odd behavior around the functionality to
include it in Annotated Container. Without a solid use-case for why
you'd need to do this the idea of a non-shared service should be handled
through the creation of a factory that's marked as a service that is
then depended on to appropriately create new instances.
